sub_topic: Probability of a certain type of consumer behavior occurring in a market
message_1: A survey of 100 consumers showed that 70% prefer to purchase products online. What is the probability that out of a random sample of 10 consumers, at least 8 prefer online shopping?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the binomial probability formula:

P(X = k) = C(n, k) * p^k * (1-p)^(n-k)

where:
- P(X = k) is the probability of exactly k successes (in this case, consumers who prefer online shopping) in n trials (in this case, a sample of 10 consumers)
- C(n, k) is the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time, also written as n! / (k!(n-k)!)
- p is the probability of success (in this case, 0.7 or 70%)
- n is the number of trials (in this case, 10)
- k is the number of successes (in this case, we want to find the probability of at least 8 successes, so we will calculate for k = 8, 9, and 10)

First, we will calculate the probabilities for k = 8, 9, and 10:

P(X = 8) = C(10, 8) * 0.7^8 * 0.3^2
P(X = 9) = C(10, 9) * 0.7^9 * 0.3^1
P(X = 10) = C(10, 10) * 0.7^10 * 0.3^0

Now, we will calculate the combinations:

C(10, 8) = 10! / (8!2!) = 45
C(10, 9) = 10! / (9!1!) = 10
C(10, 10) = 10! / (10!0!) = 1

Now, we will plug these values into the probability formula:

P(X = 8) = 45 * 0.7^8 * 0.3^2 ≈ 0.233
P(X = 9) = 10 * 0.7^9 * 0.3^1 ≈ 0.121
P(X = 10) = 1 * 0.7^10 * 0.3^0 ≈ 0.028

Finally, we will add these probabilities together to find the probability of at least 8 successes:

P(X ≥ 8) = P(X = 8) + P(X = 9) + P(X = 10) ≈ 0.233 + 0.121 + 0.028 ≈ 0.382

So, the probability that at least 8 out of 10 consumers prefer online shopping is approximately 38.2%.
